makers.displaydate: 1471–1528; born and died Nuremberg, Germany; active Venice, Italy, and Nuremburg
makers.displaymaker: Albrecht Dürer, 1471–1528; born and died Nuremberg, Germany; active Venice, Italy, and Nuremburg

texts.textentryhtml: Although he considered himself a painter first and foremost, Dürer acquired fame and fortune through his prints. He created several highly influential printed versions of the Passion narrative, in which he brought new life to the traditional imagery of Jesus’s torture and execution through expressive lines and a gift for storytelling. This woodcut and the one nearby belong to Dürer’s Large Passion series, which he completed in 1510 and published in book form the following year. Here Dürer places the figure of Christ, who has fallen under the weight of the cross, in the midst of frenzied attackers, compassionate followers, and a scampering dog. Saint Veronica, the kneeling woman on the left, is about to offer her cloth to wipe Christ’s face, while a soldier on the right confronts us with his gaze.
texts.remarks: K1-3 rotation November 2019, K1-3 Rotation May 2012
